newsitem.title: ISRAEL: Israel brushes off Clinton Jerusalem criticism.
newsitem.headline: Israel brushes off Clinton Jerusalem criticism.

text.p: Israel has brushed off U.S. President Bill Clinton's criticism of its plan to build a new Jewish neighbourhood in Arab East Jerusalem, saying work will begin on the project this week.

"I would have preferred the decision not have been made because I don't think it builds confidence. I think it builds mistrust," Clinton said at the start of a White House meeting with Palestinian President Yasser Arafat on Monday.

Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's spokesman Shai Bazak refused to comment on Clinton's criticism of Israel's decision last week to approve a plan to build 6,500 homes for Jews at Jabal Abu Ghneim hill, which Israel calls Har Homa.

But government sources were quoted by Israel's Itim news agency and by Israel's army radio as saying: "The United States always opposed Israel's policy in Jerusalem and that did not interfere with Israel building in it in the past."
Itim also said: "The government sources added that the government of Israel intended to implement its building projects throughout the city".
Bazak did say that Israel would begin surveying work for the new neighbourhood this week. "It will begin in another day or two," he told Reuters.
Israel's approval of a new Jewish settlement in Arab East Jerusalem has sparked Palestinian outrage. So far, Arafat has kept a lid on violence.
On Monday, Palestinians shut down East Jerusalem, the rest of the West Bank and the Gaza Strip in a general strike to protest the project. The strike passed without incident.
Faisal al-Husseini, top Palestine Liberation Organisation official in Jerusalem, warned it was only the beginning.

"This is a first collective step of the Palestinian people to show that they are against this matter and they are ready to do something for that even if it will cost them a price," Husseini told Israel Television.
Israel's moves in Jerusalem spurred violence in September. Sixty-one Arabs and 15 Israeli soldiers died in gunbattles after Netanyahu opened a tourist tunnel near Islamic holy shrines.

Israel captured East Jerusalem along with the West Bank and the Gaza Strip in the 1967 Middle East war. In a move not recognised internationally, it later annexed East Jerusalem, declaring it part of an indivisible capital. Palestinians want East Jerusalem to be the capital of a future state.

The sides are to begin final status peace talks within the coming weeks at which issues including Jerusalem's status, according to a framework interim peace deal, will be negotiated. The sides are to reach a final peace accord by 1999.
Palestinians view Israeli building in Arab East Jerusalem as preempting negotiations.
Alongside the decision to build for Jews, Israel said it would allow another 3,000 homes for Arabs in East Jerusalem.

Israel's Peace Now movement on Monday slammed as haphazard and unlikely to be implemented what it said was the government's one-page plan for Arab construction that it had obtained. The group did not release the document.
Peace Now's Daniel Seidemann told Reuters: "It's a hastily prepared document for purposes of public relations". Government officials were not immediately available to comment.
